【20】Brief Hospital Course:
Patient had resolution of her pneumonia (see below) but was not cleared by physical therapy for discharge. She also was not able to perform her own dressing changes. We attempted to place patient in rehab/snf but she was a difficult placement. The patient was then found to be smoking in her room then again down outside of the hospital. We explained that this was not appropriate. The following day she insisted on leaving with the wheelchair. We urged her to stay since we were not sure she was stable to ambulate on her own or do own dressing changes. She demanded to leave and signed out AGAINST MEDICAL ADVICE.

【21】Hosp course by problem:

【22】 # Hypoxia/LLL Pneumonia: CXR with evidence of LLL pneumonia. Hx of MRSA therefore started on vanco/levaquin for abx coverage. 
Blood cultures from the ED were negative and other blood cx were NGTD at time of discharge. Levaquin and vancomycin were continued for possible nosocomial vs CA pneumonia (patient had recently been hospitalized and after that had resided in a nursing home and it was felt she was at risk for hospital-acquired infection) for 4 days. After this, IV vancomycin was D/Ced and patient was continued on a total of a 10-day course of levaquin (5 days at 750mgQD and 5 days at 500mg QD). In terms of other etiologies of hypoxia/SOB: ___ was performed with 2 sets of negative cardiac enzymes and no new EKG changes. CTA was performed and showed no large central or lobar pulmonary embolus. However CTA did reveal extensive background lung disease with multifocal areas of ground-glass opacity and consolidation, which were initially felt to likely be ___underlying lung disease ___ cryoglobulinemia (there have been reports of interstitial pneumonitis in association with HepC and cryoglobulinemia) or drug-induced lung disease (patient has received multiple cytotoxic medications for attempted treatment of HepC and cryoglobulinemia). There was some concern for rituxan-induced UIP but a repeat chest CT showed almost complete resolution of the ground glass opacities on initial CT so these changes were thought to most likely be ___ an infectious process. Patient should follow up with PCP to discuss any need for further pulmonary imaging.

【23】# Severe pain: ___ ulcers, neuropathic pain, ?psychological componenet. Patient was initially given 4mg IV morphine x 3 over 3 hours in ED. She continued to complain of ___ pain on arrival to floor. After several hours on floor, patient given valium for CIWA and appeared very sleepy, yet still complaining of pain. After talking with PCP, PCP recommended switching off IV pain meds given h/o IV narcotic abuse. Patient was switched to PO MScontin and oxycodone. Gabapentin, amitryptiline,effexor, and lyrica were also given for neuropathic pain. 
Gabapentin was initially started at 300mg TID and this was titrated up to 1200mg TID over the course of the hospital stay. 
Patient was weaned off the narcotic medications MScontin and oxycodone. She complained of persistent difficulty ambulating___ pain; she was actively encouraged to ambulate on a daily basis by both staff and ___.

【24】# ___ IV Ulcers: Unclear etiology but likely secondary to severe refractory cryoglobulinemia. Xray did show evidence of osteomyelitis but this was believed to be a chronic finding given the fact that the patient's ulcers reveal exposed bone. 
Vascular surgery did see her in consult and believed that there was no clinical evidence of cellulitis, active osteomyelitis,necrotizing fasciitsi, or compartment syndrome. On exam, ulcers were deep but did not appear infected; granulation tissue present with no active bleeding or exudate. Ulcers were managed with daily wound dressing changes as per vascular surgery recommendations, as well as pain management by PO pain medications.

【25】# Elevated CK: Patient had elevated CK to ~3500 at time of presentation. This may have been ___ stasis, not moving with pain of leg ulcers, medication side effect. She had been on home lyrica which has been reported to cause elevated CK and/or rhabdo in about 2% of cases. Lyrica was initially held as inpatient. Patient given IV fluid replacement. Repeat CK trended down 3500 -> 2800 -> 1800 -> 650 and at this point lyrica was restarted given the decreasing CK as well as patient's significant pain. Over the course of the hospital admission, CK continued to trend down to around 300.

【26】# Anemia: Patient has longstanding anemia likely related to both her reported history of beta thalassemia as well as chronic blood loss from her ulcers and anemia of chronic inflammation. 
Iron studies ___ iron but also low TIBC and high Ferritin,which is most c/w anemia of chronic inflammation rather than iron deficiency anemia. Microcytosis likely ___ thalassemia. 
No treatment was given for anemia during hospital stay as supplemental iron did not seem to be indicated.

【27】# Lactic acidosis: Lactic acid elevated to 2.7 at presentation with unclear etiology, ? local tissue ischemia from ulcers. 
There was no evidence of hypoperfusion or severe hypoxemia. 
Lactate was trended and decreased from 2.7 to 1.6 over the course of the hospital stay.

【28】# Hx of substance abuse: Per patient report, she has not used illicits or ETOH in ___ yrs. Utox and serum tox negative at presentation. Monitored on CIWA scale with administration of valium for signs of severe agitation as necessary.

【29】# Cryoglobulinemia: Patient has history of Type II cryoglobulinemia most likely ___ HCV infection. Patient recently received Rituxan therapy at OSH. Rituxan is anexperimental treatment in patient who have not responded to interferon therapy. She may have extensive vasculitis leading to the ulceration, but there was no evidence of renal failure on labs. 
Per report from her rheumatologist, patient has been tried on multiple medications to treat both the hepC and the cryoglobulinemia, none of which have been tolerated or been successful. She was initially treated with interferon but had a negative reaction (severe depression) to this and it was stopped. She was also tried on plasmaphoresis (which did not help), steroids (which made her "crazy") as well as the most recent trial of rituximab. Some evidence in the literature for use of azathioprine/cyclophosphamide for treatment of refractory cryoglobulinemia, and this could possibly attempted as outpatient.

【30】# Hepatitis C: Monitored LFTs; as per above patient has h/o interferon allergy and this seems to preclude further treatment.

【44】Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted because of worsening pain in your legs as well as some shortness of breath. You had a chest Xray which showed possible pneumonia and your oxygen was low, so we started treatment with 2 antibiotics (levoquin and vancomycin) to treat this pneumonia. We continued the vancomycin for 4 days and levoquin for 10 days. Chest CAT scan showed that you initially had a lung process which could have been either infection or drug-induced process; a repeat chest CAT scan after a few days showed that this process had resolved so it was likely an infection such as pneumonia or bronchitis. We also worked as carefully as we could with your PCP to control your leg pain with oral pain medications (MS contin and oxycodone as recommended by your PCP) as well as gabapentin which we increased from 900 three times a day to 1200 three times a day,and your home dose of amitryptiline. We added effexor to better control your pain. We weaned off your narcotics prior to discharge.

【45】Please take all medications as directed. You left against our advice so we were unable to prepare prescriptions for you.

【46】If you have any problems with severely worsening leg pain or any chest pain, shortness of breath, or fevers at home please call your PCP, and if your PCP is not available please come to the nearest emergency room.

【47】You left AGAINST OUR ADVICE and signed a release form documenting this. Please see your physician tomorrow for refills on your medications.

【27】1) COPD exacerbation/Pneumonia: Upon presentation the patient had considerable wheezing bilaterally but was breathing comfortably and was not desaturating on 2L O2 by nasal cannula,which was what she had been prescribed at home. Given concern for hemoptysis and possible need for bronchoscopy, however, pulmonology consult was obtained and involved throughout her hospitalization. As she was quite wheezy on presentation and her long smoking history an element of COPD was considered quite likely to be contributing to this presentation so she was started on an aggressive COPD regimen with standing beta agonist and anti-cholinergic inhalers as well as daily long acting beta-agonist/corticosteroid inhaler. 
Further systemic corticosteroid therapy was deferred at this time given she had just completed a taper on the day prior to presentation. She also was continued on a course of antibiotics for hospital acquired pneumonia given she did have an infiltrate, though her clinical presentation did not sound completely consistent with acute bacterial pneumonia. CT scan revealed probable infiltrate as well as masses and post-radiation fibrosis consistent with her previous malignancy and treatment. Her previous imaging from ___was also reviewed by the pulmonary consult service who thought her fibrosis was essentially stable. With inhalers and antibiotics her symptoms considerably improved with resolution of her wheezing. She was transitioned to oral antibiotics and remained afebrile. At the time of discharge she was able to ambulate with an O2 saturation of 93-97% on room air. She was discharged to complete a total of ten days of antibiotic therapy. Be sure to report signs of infection. These include: increasing redness; worsening pain; new or increasing drainage, or drainage that is white, yellow, or green; or fever of 101.5 or more. (If you have taken aspirin, Tylenol, or other fever reducing medicine, wait at least ___ hours after taking it before you check your temperature in order to get an accurate reading.)
FOR SUDDEN, SEVERE BLEEDING OR SWELLING (Groin puncture site or incision)
If you have sudden, severe bleeding or swelling at either of the groin puncture sites: 
-Lie down, keep leg straight and apply (or have someone apply)firm pressure to area for ___ minutes with a gauze pad or clean cloth. 
-Once bleeding has stopped, call your surgeon to report what happened. 
-If bleeding does not stop, call ___ for transfer to closest Emergency Room. 
You may shower 48 hours after surgery. Let the soapy water run over the puncture sites, then rinse and pat dry. Do not rub these sites and do not apply cream, lotion, ointment or powder. 
Wear loose-fitting pants and clothing as this will be less irritating to the groin puncture sites. 

【26】MEDICATIONS Take aspirin daily. Aspirin helps prevent blood clots that could form in your repaired artery. Take Plavix for the next month only for the kidney and intestine stents. 
It is very important that you never stop taking aspirin or other blood thinning medicines-even for a short while- unless the surgeon who repaired your aneurysm tells you it is okay to stop. Do not stop taking them, even if another doctor or nurse tells you to, without getting an okay from the surgeon who first prescribed them. 
You will be given prescriptions for any new medication started during your hospital stayBefore you go home, your nurse ___ give you information about new medication and will review all the medications you should take at home. Be sure to ask any questions you may have. If something you normally take or may take is not on the list you receive from the nurse, please ask if it is okay to take it. 

【27】PAIN MANAGEMENT Most patients do not have much pain following this procedure. 
 Your puncture sites may be a little sore. This will improve daily. If it is getting worse, please let us knowYou will be given instructions about taking pain medicine if you need it.

【28】ACTIVITY You must limit activity to protect the puncture sites in your groin. For ONE WEEK:
-Do not drive
-Do not swim, take a tub bath or go in a Jacuzzi or hot tub
-Do not lift, push, pull or carry anything heavier than five pounds
-Do not do any exercise or activity that causes you to hold your breath or bear down with your abdominal muscles-Do not resume sexual activity Discuss with your surgeon when you may return to other regular activities, including work. If needed, we will give you a letter for your workplace. 
It is normal to feel weak and tired. This can last six-eight weeks, but should get better day by day. You may want to have help around the house during this time___ push yourself too hard during your recovery. Rest when you feel tired. Gradually return to normal activities over the next monthWe encourage you to walk regularly. Walking, especially outdoors in good weather is the best exercise for circulation. 
Walk short distances at first, even in the house, then do a little more each dayIt is okay to climb stairs. You may need to climb them slowly and pause after every few steps. 

【29】DIET It is normal to have a decreased appetite. Your appetite will return over timeFollow a well balance, heart-healthy diet, with moderate restriction of salt and fat. 
Eat small, frequent meals with nutritious food options (high fiber, lean meats, fruits, and vegetables) to maintain your strength and to help with wound healing.

【30】BOWEL AND BLADDER FUNCTION You should be able to pass urine without difficulty. Call you doctor if you have any problems urinating, such as burning,pain, bleeding, going too often, or having trouble urinating or starting the flow of urine. Call if you have a decrease in the amount of urine. 
You may experience some constipation after surgery because of pain medicine and changes in activity. Increasing fluids and fiber in your diet and staying active can help. To relief constipation, you may talk a mild laxative. Please take to your pharmacist for advice about what to take. 
SMOKING If you smoke, it is very important that you STOP. Research shows smoking makes vascular disease worse. This could increase the chance of a blockage in your new graft. Talk to your primary care physician about ways to quit smoking.

o Tomorrow you may shower and remove the gauzes over your incisions. Under these dressing you have small plastic bandages called steri-strips. Do not remove steri-strips for 2 weeks.

o Constipation is a common side effect of narcotic pain medications. o It is normal to feel some discomfort/pain following abdominal surgery. This pain is often described as "soreness". 
o Your pain should get better day by day. If you find the pain is getting worse instead of better, please contact your surgeono You will receive a prescription for pain medicine to take by mouth. It is important to take this medicine as directed. o Do not take it more frequently than prescribed. Do not take more medicine at one time than prescribedo Your pain medicine will work better if you take it before your pain gets too severeo Talk with your surgeon about how long you will need to take prescription pain medicine. Please don't take any other pain medicine, including non-prescription pain medicine, unless your surgeon has said its okayo If you are experiencing no pain, it is okay to skip a dose of pain medicineo Remember to use your "cough pillow" for splinting when you cough or when you are doing your deep breathing exercisesIf you experience any of the following, please contact your surgeon:

【25】This information is designed as a guideline to assist you in a speedy recovery from your surgery. Please follow these guidelines unless your physician has specifically instructed you otherwise. Please call our office nurse if you have any questions. Dial 911 if you have any medical emergency.

【26】ACTIVITY: 
There are restrictions on activity. On the side of your transmetatarsal amputation you are non weight bearing for ___weeks. You should keep this amputation site elevated when ever possible. 
You may use the heel of your amputation site for transfer and pivots. But try not to exert too much pressure on the site when transferring and or pivoting. If possible avoid using the heel of your amputation site when transferring and pivotingNo driving until cleared by your Surgeon.

【27】PLEASE CALL US IMMEDIATELY FOR ANY OF THE FOLLOWING PROBLEMS:
Redness in or drainage from your leg wound(s)New pain, numbness or discoloration of your foot or toesWatch for signs and symptoms of infection. These are: a fever greater than 101 degrees, chills, increased redness, or pus draining from the incision site. If you experience any of these or bleeding at the incision site, CALL THE DOCTOR.

【28】Exercise:
Limit strenuous activity for 6 weeks. 
Do not drive a car unless cleared by your Surgeon. 
No heavy lifting greater than 20 pounds for the next ___ days. 
Try to keep leg elevated when able.

【29】BATHING/SHOWERING: 
You may shower immediately upon coming home. No bathing. A dressing may cover youre amputation site and this should be left in place for three (3) days. Remove it after this time and wash your incision(s) gently with soap and water. You will have sutures, which are usually removed in 4 weeks. This will be done by the Surgeon on your ___ appointment.

【30】WOUND CARE:
Sutures / Staples may be removed before discharge. If they are not, an appointment will be made for you to return for staple removal. 
When the sutures are removed the doctor may or may not place pieces of tape called steri-strips over the incision. These will stay on about a week and you may shower with them on. If these do not fall off after 10 days, you may peel them off with warm water and soap in the showerAvoid taking a tub bath, swimming, or soaking in a hot tub for four weeks after surgery.

【31】MEDICATIONS: 
Unless told otherwise you should resume taking all of the medications you were taking before surgery. You will be given a new prescription for pain medication, which can be taken every three (3) to four (4) hours only if necessary. 
Remember that narcotic pain meds can be constipating and you should increase the fluid and bulk foods in your diet. (Check with your physician if you have fluid restrictions.) If you feel that you are constipated, do not strain at the toilet. You may use over the counter Metamucil or Milk of Magnesia. Appetite suppression may occur; this will improve with time. Eat small balanced meals throughout the dayCAUTIONS:
NO SMOKING! We know you've heard this before, but it really is an important step to your recovery. Smoking causes narrowing of your blood vessels which in turn decreases circulation. If you smoke you will need to stop as soon as possible. Ask your nurse or doctor for information on smoking cessationAvoid pressure to your amputation site. No strenuous activity for 6 weeks after surgery.

【32】DIET:
There are no special restrictions on your diet postoperatively. 
Poor appetite is expected for several weeks and small, frequent meals may be preferred. 
For people with vascular problems we would recommend a cholesterol lowering diet: Follow a diet low in total fat and low in saturated fat and in cholesterol to improve lipid profile in your blood. Additionally, some people see a reduction in serum cholesterol by reducing dietary cholesterol. Since a reduction in dietary cholesterol is not harmful, we suggest that most people reduce dietary fat, saturated fat and cholesterol to decrease total cholesterol and LDL (Low Density Lipoprotein-the bad cholesterol). Exercise will increase your HDL (High Density Lipoprotein-the good cholesterol) and with your doctor's permission, is typically recommended. You may be self-referred or get a referral from your doctor.
